text:
JUST IN: The Golden State Warriors have selected James Wiseman with the No. 2 pick in the #NBADraft. 

https://t.co/r6yNV4gz48

name: sfchronicle
text: Wiseman, 19, was selected after Minnesota took Georgia shooting guard Anthony Edwards at No. 1. A 7-foot-1, 247-pounder, Wiseman could have a chance to slide into the Warriors’ starting lineup as a rookie. https://t.co/5R3gb2CQVx

name: sfchronicle
text:
One way that Giusti and Recology sought to satisfy Nuru, federal officials said, was by providing a temporary job for Nuru’s son in 2015, 2016 and 2017, corresponding with the rate-increase application process.

https://t.co/dVdM65peu8

name: sfchronicle
text:
The Warriors elicited a ton of social media attention when they had the potential to make a franchise-altering transaction with the No. 2 overall pick. 

Some, however, were still focused on a Klay Thompson injury.

https://t.co/7K379ccP7h

name: sfchronicle
text:

text: With a week to go before Thanksgiving, the country is grappling with a coronavirus surge that is expected to kill thousands. And family conflict over how or whether to gather has escalated to new heights in the Bay Area. https://t.co/CRFtdD99du https://t.co/9LM3UuZXDy

text:

https://t.co/LXQ3F6K68R https://t.co/9zVNBEKOOM

text: Drinking with Esther: A Berkeley winemaker lost most of his 2020 red wines to smoke taint. So he fermented pressed-off juice of Sauvignon Blanc grapes with the juice of heirloom pears.   https://t.co/jE5cBpdsoB https://t.co/hoIwufGDD5

name: sfchronicle
text:
The world’s biggest firebreak — a nearly 800-mile line cut into the Sierra Nevada during the Great Depression — once protected California’s forests from the state’s ceaseless infernos.

What happened to the Ponderosa Way? https://t.co/eHiDB3K8jL

https://t.co/q41zoWD6pL https://t.co/sdtTZglB2H

name: sfchronicle
text:

“Last week, Europe registered over 29,000 new COVID-19 deaths," said Hans Kluge. https://t.co/IJvLPxFcmd

text:

name: sfchronicle
text:
The University of California piloted an opt-in smartphone app to track the spread of the virus at UCSD and UCSF. Using Bluetooth, the app tracks every person someone has come within 6 feet, and alerts them if they were near a person who tested positive.

https://t.co/Z9HGKh35Ax

name: sfchronicle
text:
Gov. Gavin Newsom said this week he was considering a statewide curfew to control the spread of the coronavirus. But experts are mixed on whether such measures have any tangible effect.

https://t.co/xtfyS5u5Uv

text:
“The future of Bay Area transit appears bleak, absent a significant infusion of additional operating funds on an emergency basis,” read the letter to the MTC from nearly four dozen advocacy groups.

https://t.co/LNsbloS9LU

text:

name: sfchronicle
text: BREAKING: Gov. Newsom announces curfew requiring non-essential work and gatherings to stop between 10 p.m. and 5 a.m. in counties in the purple tier. https://t.co/8E11Jl8FYm

name: sfchronicle
text:
The curfew is slated to take effect Saturday at 10 p.m. for one month. 

The announcement comes amid soaring case counts, rising hospitalizations and a looming holiday that has the nation on edge.

https://t.co/DrtuXM7RHA

name: sfchronicle
text:
"The virus doesn’t care — day or night."

Some experts are skeptical that a curfew measure would do much to slow the spread of the coronavirus in the Bay Area, or anywhere else. https://t.co/wVOr2bQcqP

name: sfchronicle
text:
Counties affected by the new California overnight curfew include Alameda, Contra Costa, Napa, Santa Clara, Sonoma and Solano in the Bay Area. The curfew will not apply to San Francisco, San Mateo and Marin counties.

https://t.co/e3MjsY7C8c
